Hi guys, 

I appreciate all the feedback I am getting. I understand that TD=
D is 
a design activity , however what I wish to tackle is the test-first 
=
concept of TDD. I realise that there are many phases to TDD, but it 
seems =
what people have problems with is the idea of writing the 
tests before wri=
ting the code. With that in mind, I figured if i 
could help autogenerate s=
ome basic testing codes to get them off on 
a start, they could get the han=
g of it and probably improve on the 
tests generated later.



Erm does tha=
t make sense?


Most other tools out there requires additional installation=
 etc, 
which is why I hope to build on JUnit's core code itself to generate=
 
the additional test cases. In such a way, the user probably won't 
need a=
ny additional application, just an updated version of the 
JUnit jar file f=
or eclipse plugin or whatever?

I am kinda new at this and would appreciate=
 any help or suggestions

Thanks a bunch,
Jimm
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com=
, "Andrew McDonagh" <andrewmcdonagh@...> 
wrote:
>
> On 12/27/06, chet hend=
rickson <lists@...> wrote:
> > Hello Jimm,
> >
> > I can imagine some benef=
it from generating some asserts as part 
of the
> > second or third pass of=
 test creation.  Remember that TDD is a
> > /design/ activity, not a testin=
g activity.  I am afraid that 
generated
> > assertions would break the bas=
ic cycle feedback of TDD.
> >
> > I am not going to tell you not to do this=
 project, but calling 
it TDD
> > would cause me to call into question your=
 understanding of TDD.
> >
> > chet
> 
> Agreed, essentially Jim, what you =
are describing (to me at least) 
is
> automating the unit testing of code. =
 It does not sound like TDD.
> 
> And there's nothing wrong with that - JUn=
it is a tool that makes no
> assumptions on what design process we use.
> 
=
> Indeed, there are already several tools out there that can
> autogenerate=
 JUnit tests for code, and still others that 'play' 
with
> the byte code t=
o see if your unit tests are actually any good at
> testing.  However, none=
 of these tools are aimed at TDD, they are
> aimed at Unit Testing.
> 
> ht=
h
> 
> Good luck with the course
> 
> Andrew
